2.5.1.title: Overview
2.5.1.content:
Bullheading forces well fluids back into the formation without circulation.

**Concept:**
- Pump into wellbore at pressure exceeding formation fracture pressure
- Fluids (including kick) forced into formation
- Does not require circulation path

**When Used:**
- Cannot circulate (stuck pipe, plugged bit, no returns)
- Well producing and cannot establish circulation
- Emergency situation requiring rapid control
- When circulation methods impractical

**Limitations:**
- Requires formation to accept fluid (permeability)
- May damage formation
- Does not remove kick - pushes it into formation
- May cause underground flow if formation has lateral permeability
- Pressures can be high

**Risks:**
- Formation damage
- Underground blowout
- Casing failure
- Surface equipment limits exceeded

2.5.2.title: Planning
2.5.2.content:
Bullheading requires careful planning:

**Assess:**
- Formation characteristics (porosity, permeability)
- Previous LOT/FIT results at shoe
- Open hole length and formations exposed
- Casing and wellhead ratings
- Pump capabilities
- Expected pressure requirements

**Calculate:**
- Expected surface pressure = Fracture pressure - Hydrostatic head of fluid
- Compare to casing/wellhead ratings
- Account for friction pressure at planned rate

**Fluid Selection:**
- Kill weight mud preferred (adds hydrostatic)
- Heavyweight brine options
- Volume required (well volume + formation acceptance)

**Equipment:**
- High-pressure pump (cementing unit or rig pumps)
- Adequate surface pressure ratings
- Pressure monitoring equipment
- Relief systems

2.5.3.title: Procedure
2.5.3.content:
**Preparation:**
1. Review well data and calculate expected pressures
2. Verify equipment ratings exceed expected pressure
3. Prepare kill fluid - sufficient volume
4. Line up pump to drillpipe or annulus (as appropriate)
5. Establish communication with all personnel
6. Brief crew on procedure and abort criteria

**Execution:**
1. Start pumping slowly
2. Increase rate until formation takes fluid
3. Monitor pressure - should stabilize when formation accepting
4. Continue pumping at rate that maintains acceptance
5. Monitor volume pumped vs well volume
6. Watch for pressure changes indicating breakthrough to other zones

**Completion:**
- Pump sufficient volume to displace wellbore and fill formation
- Reduce rate and monitor for flow back
- If successful: pressure bleeds off, well stable
- Flow check to confirm kill

2.5.4.title: Monitoring and Abort Criteria
2.5.4.content:
**Monitor Throughout:**
- Surface pressure
- Pump rate and volume
- Returns (should be none during bullhead)
- Any signs of abnormal behavior

**Warning Signs:**
- Pressure increasing above expected (plugging)
- Pressure decreasing unexpectedly (lost to another zone)
- Surface leaks or equipment problems
- Returns when none expected

**Abort Criteria:**
- Pressure approaching equipment limits
- Evidence of flow to surface (losing battle)
- Equipment failure
- Formation not accepting (pressure rises without acceptance)

**If Aborted:**
- Shut in and reassess
- Consider alternative methods
- Evaluate formation response
- Consult with experts if needed

2.5.5.title: Post-Bullhead Actions
2.5.5.content:
**After Successful Bullhead:**
1. Monitor well for flow back
2. Maintain pressure monitoring
3. Plan next steps:
   - Resume operations if appropriate
   - Evaluate formation damage
   - Consider clean-up circulation

**Considerations:**
- Formation may be damaged - affects future production
- Fluids forced into formation may migrate
- Monitor adjacent wells if in developed field
- Document volumes and pressures for future reference

**If Bullhead Unsuccessful:**
- Well may still be flowing
- Evaluate other options:
  - Relief well
  - Additional bullhead attempts
  - Well capping
- Consult with well control specialists
